page.title: 05FISHING OFF SOUTH SELSEY
page.content: A very old fisherman told us about his life.He began fishing when he was 17 and finished when he was 70.He was Coxswain of the Lifeboat exactly 100 years after his grandfather was Coxswain.Many of today's fishermen are from families who have fished here for generations. Lots of pots are put down for{crabs and{lobsters}near rocks eight miles out and then they are winched in and stacked by a second "hand".The first "hand" holds the tiller and the third "hand" can be an apprentice.There are still vacancies for third "hands". {Cockles,whelks}and{prawns}are caught. The best time for prawns is at low tide and a full moon.This may mean getting up at 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning.The best time for{mackerel}is May but there are not so many as there used to be because of the groynes.
